data.title: Creativity Summit
data.text:
Dates: April 7-9, 2016 Location: Columbus Museum of Art

Commit to creativity and become a creative change agent in your world by attending our 2016 Creativity Summit conference. Creativity has been described as the most critical human skill for the 21st century. The Summit is a participatory forum for cultivating creativity and catalyzing change in our lives, communities, and beyond. The three-day conference will include workshops, networking, and national and local speakers including comic Tig Notaro, and authors Tony Wagner and Warren Berger.

Daytime sessions are $75 per day and include lunch. A 3-day, early-bird registration pass is available for $200 through March 18. The Thursday evening Tig Notaro performance is a stand-alone ticket not included in the 3-day pass. For more information, please call 614.629.0359.

Register

Highlights of the 2016 Creativity Summit:

Day 1: Wonder, Awe, and Questioning: Habits of Creativity

Thursday April 7, 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM What dispositions support the creative process, and how might we cultivate them for ourselves and others? What is wonder, what role does it play in the imaginative and critical process of creativity?

Presenters: Sean Foley, Artist, educator, and curator Warren Berger, author of A More Beautiful Question

Creative Conversation with Comedienne Tig Notaro

Thursday April 7, 6:00 – 9:00 PM From John Cleese to the RAND Corporation, many draw a connection between the attributes of comedy and creativity. During this special evening program, comic Tig Notaro explores her creative process and what it means to think like a comic. This evening performance is a stand-alone ticket, which is not included in the Creativity Summit 3-day pass. General public tickets available for $30 per person.

Day 2: Space, Time, and Inclusion: Conditions of Creativity

Friday April 8, 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM What factors create a fertile soil for creativity to thrive? Examine some key conditions that can be leveraged to support the creative process in particular the ways that physical space and the engagement of diverse perspectives can promote innovative thinking.

Presenters: Dr. David Staley, Associate Professor of History and Design, Goldberg Center, Ohio State University Dr. Melissa Crum, Cultural Strategist and Education Consultant, Mosaic Education Network

Most Likely to Succeed Community Screening

Friday, Apr. 8, 6:00 – 8:00 pm View and discuss the documentary, Most Likely to Succeed, based on the book by Tony Wagner. This program is free and open to the community and registration is requested in advance.

Day 3: Making Creativity Visible: Promoting Creativity in Learning

Saturday April 9, 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM How can we reimagine learning to promote the conditions and cultivate the thinking dispositions of creativity? What does creativity look like, feel like, and sound like in learning? How can creativity be modeled, fostered, and assessed?

Presenters: Dr. Tony Wagner, Education innovation expert, and co-author of Most Likely to Succeed: Preparing Our Kids for the Innovation Era Stephanie Rond, street artist, founder and director of S.Dot Gallery, and co-founder of Creative Arts of Women (CAW)

Click here to download the Full Creativity Summit Schedule.

Creative Conversation with Tig Notaro is sponsored by Continental Office. Most Likely to Succeed is presented with the support of the Martha Holden Jennings Foundation, in conjunction with their Leadership Series. Saturday sessions are part of Making Creativity Visible, an initiative funded by the Institute of Museum and Library Services.
